subsections.title: Climbing Safety
subsections.label: subsec:climb-safety2
prompts: Explain the importance of proper grounding techniques for lightning protection on towers, focusing on the use of short and direct connections.
Describe the essential safety practices for climbing antenna towers, including the use of climbing harnesses and tie-offs.
Discuss the risks associated with climbing towers without a helper or observer and why it is never safe to do so.
Outline the safety precautions to observe when installing an antenna tower, particularly in relation to overhead electrical wires.
Explain the purpose of a safety wire through a turnbuckle used to tension guy lines and how it prevents loosening due to vibration.
Detail the minimum safe distance required from power lines when installing an antenna and the rationale behind this distance.
Discuss the safety rules specific to crank-up towers, including the prohibition of climbing unless the tower is retracted or has mechanical safety locking devices.
Describe proper grounding methods for towers, emphasizing the use of separate ground rods for each tower leg and bonding requirements.
Explain why attaching an antenna to a utility pole is discouraged, focusing on the risk of contact with high-voltage power lines.
Discuss the guidelines for installing grounding conductors used for lightning protection, particularly the avoidance of sharp bends.
Identify the regulatory body or standard that establishes grounding requirements for amateur radio towers or antennas, emphasizing the role of local electrical codes.
